author: Claire Campbell
title: Injured BMX champion Sam Willoughby making progress, SA Government raises funds for rehabilitation - ABC News (Australian Broadcasting Corporation)
text:
Map: Adelaide 5000 
Olympian Sam Willoughby is making good progress with his rehabilitation from a serious spinal injury and dreams of walking down the aisle at his wedding later this year, according to his father. 
The two-time world champion BMX rider and Olympic silver medallist suffered a career-ending spinal injury during a training accident in the United States of America last year. 
Willoughby has since returned from Colorado to his home in San Francisco where he is undergoing physiotherapy four times a week. 
The South Australian Government is auctioning off a hot lap in a V8 race car on Friday at the Clipsal 500 with champion driver Lee Holdsworth in a bid to help with the expenses of Willoughby's recovery. 
Willoughby's father, Colin, said the money raised would go towards his son's ongoing medical costs and buying rehab equipment. 
"He puts into his rehab just as hard as he put in to his training so if anyone's going to make it, he will," he said. 
"He's now able to get onto a static bike and hold himself up, do some sit-ups; he's still gaining balance and hasn't got leg movement as such but he's certainly getting there. 
"He did tell me a couple of weeks ago he has dreams at night of him walking again and also dreams of racing again." 
Willoughby's number one goal at the moment is to learn to walk, hopefully in time for his wedding on New Year's Eve. Photo: Sam Willoughby is aiming to walk at his wedding later this year. (Twitter: Sam Willoughby (@SW91)) 
The 25-year-old has recently started rehabilitation with personal trainer Eric Harness, who also helped Australian snowboarder Josh Wood get back on his feet and walk again after he suffered a spinal cord injury in 2000. 
"Mentally, he's amazed me with his strength, sure he's had a couple of moments but we all have moments everyday ... and his moments don't last," his father said. 
"His positiveness is just amazing; I just don't know how he can be as strong as he is with it. 
"I think being back in his own environment and his own house has really helped; he just goes at it that hard that the PT has to sometimes tell him to back off because he'll make himself too tired." 
Mr Willoughby said his son was "over the moon" with the support from Australians and hoped to return to Adelaide for a visit later this year. Fundraising for 'all-round nice guy' 
His Road2Recovery Foundation has already raised more than $248,000 and Tourism Minister Leon Bignell hoped money raised from the hot lap auction would tip it past the $250,000 mark. 
"I think all South Australians were really touched by what had happened and people just wanted to help," he said. 
"And as a Government we looked around and there were a few things that we had in the cupboard that we thought we could auction off to go to the fundraiser. 
"It's going to a great cause, Sam Willoughby, a terrific South Australian, obviously a great athlete ... but all-round nice guy as well." 
Bids have opened at $500 with the online auction set to close Tuesday afternoon before the hot lap takes place on Friday afternoon.
